I have a question: why do rainbows represent Pride? I ask this because I see rainbows as symbolical for other things as well and I wonder where the idea came from.
Gilbert Baker wanted to make a flag to unite the community under when the community was starting to organize and protest back in the day. Each color represents something different.

I was wondering that, too. Originally, at least in western culture, the rainbow had religious importance. Specifically, it was a sign to Noah's family after the flood that there would never be another flood that would destroy mankind. In contrast, the combination of colors representing gay pride used to be red, gold and green. (The song "Karma Chameleon" makes a reference to this.) I'm not sure how that all got shuffled around.

I really, really, really don't see what a net three people saw in this that was problematic enough to downvote it. I'm sick of having polite and (what I thought were) non-controversial statements of fact down-voted with no reason given. Please, to anyone who reads this, if you're going to downvote a comment that doesn't have a response saying what the problem with the comment is, then write one.

It's actually pretty simple. Karma Chameleon came out in '83, and Gilbert Baker created the Pride flag in '78. So you're using a song that was created after the original flag was, to say that the original colors were red, gold, and green. And furthermore, the colors all stand for something.


Red ~ Life
Orange ~ Healing
Yellow ~ Sunlight
Green ~	Nature
Indigo ~ Serenity
Violet ~ Spirit

The original had hot pink, and turquoise as well.

TLDR It didn't get shuffled around. The flag was created before Karma Chameleon.

What is pride month for

Pride month attempts to celebrate those who are typically marginalized by society who are part of the LGBT+ community. Basically, if you don't like "who you're supposed to", like if you're a girl and you like another girl. A lot of people get shut out of society for that so this month celebrates those people.

Not that I'm against pride month specifically, I dislike any of these "celebration" months for identity we have no control over. Just seems superfluous, as why would you restrict being proud of who you are to a single month? Or for that matter, why take pride in it at all and just take pride in your accomplishments that may or may not have to do with your sexuality/race/etc.

Plus, in Western society, people are celebrated at a far greater rate than those who persecute them. The irony is the true minorities are those who hate these "marginalized" people. It's pretty much normalized here. Now, I have to give huge respect to those with the courage to have pride in things like this in a country in the middle east or Africa. Or China, or North Korea or Vietnam or...Yeah, the rest of the world has a long way to go.

Not necessarily an illness, it was reclassified to gender dysphoria from Gender Identity Disorder in 2013. Gender Dysphoria is the discomfort many trans people feel when their gender and designated sex at birth do not match their gender identity. It's not the same thing as being transgender, its a feeling many trans people experience before transitioning. It can be treated through transitioning and acceptance of others. 

Calling being transgender (or dealing with gender dysphoria) an "illness" can be dangerous as it signifies that there is something wrong that needs to be fixed, with most people jumping to the conclusion that the "cure" is to stop them from expressing their gender identity, rather than accepting and supporting it (the actual treatment to dysphoria listed in credible scientific journals). Keep in mind that this conversation has happened with homosexuality too, which was removed from the DSM as an illness in 1973. Sometimes the mix of politics and science prevents progress.

I hope this helped you understand. There are a lot of willfully ignorant people in these comments, but for the ones who genuinely want to understand there's plenty of credible authentic information out there.

Body dysmorphia in general, not exclusive to "trans" people is a mental illness and delusion.  The perception of self being incongruent with the reality of the self, be that in the form of anorexia, bulimia, body-builder dysmorphia, or any other example of perceiving the body as "incorrect" are delusions.  
There are skinny people who look in the mirror and believe they're supposed to be fat.
There are normal people who look in the mirror and see themselves as morbidly obese.
There are people who look in the mirror and don't think their muscles are big enough
There are people who believe they're supposed to be animals
There are people who believe they were born the wrong sex.

This is a mental illness and treating it as "normal" is obscenely dangerous given the fact that there are numerous disorders which seem to mirror the symptoms of "gender dysphoria" including bipolar, borderline personality disorder, and there is a seemingly correlative link between autism and gender identity issues.

https://williamsinstitute.law.ucla.edu/wp-content/uploads/AFSP-Williams-Suicide-Report-Final.pdf

The suicide rate does not decline post operative but actually increases, there's a serious problem when the supposed prescribed treatment kills more people than those who do not seek treatment.
